children.subject: 16B is one of the most important classes, and has been super revamped because of Sahai. Definitely worth taking - gives intro to controls, circuits, signals, DFT type stuff, systems, and a solid foundation for lin alg.

Agree with the anon above. I'm still more into CS and am currently taking 16B with Sahai. I thought I'd hate it, but woah a lot of the stuff we're learning is really cool. It's more work than some of my upperdivs and requires you be diligent in keeping up with lectures and discussions, but that just means we get to go all the more deeper into the content. It's definitely made me appreciate the beauty and intuitiveness of EE in general a lot more. If you're interested in EE because of 16A, then I definitely recommend taking 16B. It's usually a better idea to ensure you get the foundations down; you'll get a better idea of which areas you'd truly find fascinating and also be comfortable enough with the material to maybe take more than the recommended workload later on.
Oh and especially considering you're interested in doing robotics, the EE16B labs are absolutely essential for building fundamentals.

I only have one piece of advice so I'll leave the students' answer blank: In my opinion, EE16B is not very useful. Even though 16B is a pre-req for EE120, EE120 (with Babak at least) covers almost everything from the ground up. So maybe skip 16B (maybe self-study the DFT and filter section) and go right into EE120. Also I felt like EE120 was really only useful if you also take EE123 (digital signal processing) because 120 really just covers all the math, 123 goes over more applications.

EE120 is one of my favorite classes I've ever taken (I'm also LSCS)! And if you think you might be interested in EE you should definitely take it. It's not that much work and the concepts and intuition and math is beautiful :) Also there are lots of super cool and useful applications using pretty much only the basics of what is taught in 120.

I find the way of thinking in the class very different from CS classes and I vaguely feel like that helps me with general technical/mathematical maturity, but who knows.

I agree that EE16B need not be a hard prerequisite for EE120, but talks about way more parts of EE than just signals and systems, so is definitely worth taking just for exposure.

history.content: I'm a 3rd year LSCS looking to go into more ee and robotics. I don't have a lot of time left and am only currently doing ee16a. Is it worth going into ee16b -> ee120 -> ee196? or is my time better of doing more of the typical cs classes, 189, d100, etc
history.subject: EE courses
